about.page.community.members.info.value: Explore data about communities across the U.S., including your own, and provide feedback on the tool.

about.page.federal.pm.info.value: Download the tool’s current list of communities, explore data that may be useful to your program, and provide feedback on the tool.

about.page.join.open.source.info.value: The tool’s code is open source, which means it is available for the public to view and contribute to it.

about.page.send.feedback.info.value: Have ideas about data and information that reflect the experiences and conditions of your community?

children.value: Tackling the Climate Crisis at Home and Abroad

about.page.sub.header.1.text.1.value: , President Biden directed the Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) to create a Climate and Economic Justice Screening Tool. The purpose of the tool is to help Federal agencies identify disadvantaged communities that are marginalized, underserved, and overburdened by pollution. The current version of the tool provides socioeconomic, environmental, and climate information to inform decisions that may affect these communities. The tool identifies disadvantaged communities through publicly-available, nationally-consistent datasets.

about.page.sub.header.1.text.2.value: The current version of the tool is in a public beta form and will be updated based on feedback and research.

about.page.sub.header.2.text.1.value: The tool will provide important information for the Justice40 Initiative. The goal of the Justice40 Initiative is to provide 40 percent of the overall benefits of certain Federal investments in seven key areas to disadvantaged communities. These seven key areas are: climate change, clean energy and energy efficiency, clean transit, affordable and sustainable housing, training and workforce development, the remediation and reduction of legacy pollution, and the development of critical clean water infrastructure.

explore.tool.page.side.panel.info.para1.value: This tool identifies communities that are marginalized, underserved, and overburdened by pollution. These communities are located in census tracts that are at or above the thresholds in one or more of eight categories of criteria.

explore.tool.page.side.panel.info.para2.value: The tool uses census tracts that represent about 4,000 people, which is the smallest unit of geography for which consistent data can be displayed on the tool.

explore.tool.page.side.panel.info.para3.value: The tool ranks each census tract using percentiles that show how much burden each tract experiences relative to all other tracts, for each criteria.

explore.tool.page.side.panel.info.para4.value: Percentages are used for certain variables, i.e. those relating to high school achievement rate and to the share of individuals not currently enrolled in higher education.

explore.tool.page.side.panel.info.para5.value: Thresholds for each category determine if a tract should be identified as disadvantaged because it has exceeded a certain value for the relevant indicators.

explore.tool.page.side.panel.send.feedba.value: Please provide feedback about this census tract, including about the datasets, the data categories provided for this census tract, the communities who live in this census tract, and anything else relevant that CEQ should know about this census tract.

explore.tool.page.under.map.note.on.terr.value: A note on the U.S. territories
The data sources described on the
page are used to identify disadvantaged communities in all fifty states and the District of Columbia. However, not all of these data sources are currently available for the U.S. territories.

For Puerto Rico, the Census Bureau’s American Community Survey data from 2015-2019 are used for higher ed enrollment rate and all the other fields in the Training and Workforce Development category to identify disadvantaged communities. Data in the other categories are unavailable at this time.

For American Samoa and the Northern Mariana Islands, the data used to identify disadvantaged communities are from the 2010 Decennial Census, the last reported data from the U.S. Census Bureau. Available data for these territories includes unemployment, poverty, low median income, and high school degree achievement rate fields in the Training and Workforce Development category.
Work is currently underway to identify disadvantaged communities and update the tool accordingly for Guam and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

explore.tool.page.under.map.note.on.trib.value: The tool covers all U.S. census tracts, including those located within Tribal Nations, to the extent that data is available (see our

page for more information). CEQ is engaging in consultation and coordination with Tribal Nations on the beta version of the tool to provide Tribal Nations with meaningful opportunities for input, consistent with CEQ’s

indicator.categories.clean.water.title.value: Critical clean water and wasterwater infrastructure

indicator.categories.legacy.pollution.ti.value: Reduction and remediation of legacy pollution

methodology.page.categories.title.value: Communities are identified as disadvantaged by the current version of the tool for the purposes of the Justice40 Initiative if they are located in census tracts that are at or above the thresholds in one or more of eight categories of criteria below.

methodology.page.category.and.clause.hs..value: 10% or more of adults 25 or older have not attained a
AND 80% or more of individuals 15 or older are not enrolled in

methodology.page.category.and.clause.low.value: AND 80% or more of individuals 15 or older are not enrolled in

methodology.page.category.asthma.descrip.value: Weighted percent of people who answer “yes” to both of the following questions: “Have you ever been told by a doctor, nurse, or other health professional that you have asthma?” and “Do you still have asthma?”

methodology.page.category.diabetes.descr.value: Weighted percent of people ages 18 years and older who report having ever been told by a doctor, nurse, or other health professionals that they have diabetes other than diabetes during pregnancy.

methodology.page.category.diesel.pm.desc.value: Mixture of particles that is part of diesel exhaust in the air. The value in the fields is the weight of these particles in micrograms per cubic meter.

methodology.page.category.energy.burden..value: Average annual energy cost per household ($) divided by average household income.

methodology.page.category.exp.agr.loss.r.value: Percent of agricultural value at risk from losses due to fourteen types of natural hazards that have some link to climate change: avalanche, coastal flooding, cold wave, drought, hail, heat wave, hurricane, ice storm, landslide, riverine flooding, strong wind, tornado, wildfire, and winter weather. Rate calculated by dividing the agricultural value at risk in a census tract by the total agricultural value in that census tract.

methodology.page.category.exp.bld.loss.r.value: Percent of building value at risk from losses due to fourteen types of natural hazards that have some link to climate change: avalanche, coastal flooding, cold wave, drought, hail, heat wave, hurricane, ice storm, landslide, riverine flooding, strong wind, tornado, wildfire, and winter weather. Rate calculated by dividing the building value at risk in a census tract by the total building value in that census tract.

methodology.page.category.exp.pop.loss.r.value: Rate relative to the population of fatalities and injuries due to fourteen types of natural hazards each year that have some link to climate change: avalanche, coastal flooding, cold wave, drought, hail, heat wave, hurricane, ice storm, landslide, riverine flooding, strong wind, tornado, wildfire, and winter weather. Population loss is defined as the Spatial Hazard Events and Losses and National Centers for Environmental Information’s (NCEI) reported number of fatalities and injuries caused by the hazard occurrence. To combine fatalities and injuries for the computation of population loss value, an injury is counted as one-tenth (1/10) of a fatality. The NCEI Storm Events Database classifies injuries and fatalities as direct or indirect. Both direct and indirect injuries and fatalities are counted as population loss. This total number of injuries and fatalities is then divided by the population in the census tract to get a per-capita rate of population risk.

methodology.page.category.heart.disease..value: Weighted percent of people ages 18 years and older who report ever having been told by a doctor, nurse, or other health professionals that they had angina or coronary heart disease.

methodology.page.category.high.ed.enroll.value: Percent of people 15 or older who are not currently enrolled in college, university, or graduate school.

methodology.page.category.highschool.des.value: Percent of people age 25 years or older in a census tract whose education level is less than a high school diploma.

methodology.page.category.house.burden.d.value: Percent of households in a census tract that are both earning less than 80% of HUD Area Median Family Income by county and are spending more than 30% of their income on housing costs.

methodology.page.category.lead.paint.des.value: Percent of housing units built pre-1960, used as an indicator of potential lead paint exposure in census tracts with median home values less than the 90th percentile.

methodology.page.category.linguistic.iso.value: Percent of households where no one over the age 14 speaks English well.

methodology.page.category.low.income.des.value: Percent of a census tract's population in households where household income is at or below 200% of the Federal poverty level.

methodology.page.category.low.life.expec.value: Average number of years of life a person who has attained a given age can expect to live.

The percentiles for this dataset have been reversed so that census tracts with lower numbers have higher life expectancies and the census tracts with higher numbers have lower life expectancy when compared to life expectancy in the area.

methodology.page.category.low.median.exp.value: The percentiles for this dataset have been reversed so that census tracts with lower numbers have higher median incomes and census tracts with the higher numbers have lower median income when compared to area median income.

methodology.page.category.median.home.va.value: Median home value of owner-occupied housing units in the census tract.

methodology.page.category.pm2.5.descript.value: Fine inhalable particles, with diameters that are generally 2.5 micrometers and smaller. The value in the fields is the weight of these particles in micrograms per cubic meter.

methodology.page.category.poverty.descri.value: Percent of a census tract's population in households where the household income is at or below 100% of the Federal poverty level.

methodology.page.category.prox.haz.descr.value: Count of hazardous waste facilities (Treatment, Storage, and Disposal Facilities and Large Quantity Generators) within 5 kilometers (or nearest beyond 5 kilometers), each divided by distance in kilometers.

methodology.page.category.prox.npl.descr.value: Count of proposed or listed NPL - also known as Superfund - sites within 5 kilometers (or nearest one beyond 5 kilometers), each divided by distance in kilometers.

methodology.page.category.prox.rmp.descr.value: Count of RMP (potential chemical accident management plan) facilities within 5 kilometers (or nearest one beyond 5 kilometers), each divided by distance in kilometers.

children.value: U.S. Small-Area Life Expectancy Estimates Project (USALEEP)
Fusion of model and monitor data

methodology.page.category.source.epa.oar.value: as compiled by EPA’s EJScreen, sourced from EPA National Air Toxics Assessment (NATA) and the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) traffic data

children.value: Treatment, Storage, and Disposal Facilities (TSDF) data

methodology.page.category.source.epa.tsd.value: calculated from EPA's RCRA database as compiled by EPA's EJScreen

methodology.page.category.traffic.vol.de.value: Count of vehicles (average annual daily traffic) at major roads within 500 meters, divided by distance in meters.

methodology.page.category.unemploy.descr.value: Number of unemployed people as a percentage of the civilian labor force.

methodology.page.category.waste.water.de.value: Risk-Screening Environmental Indicators (RSEI) modeled toxic concentrations at stream segments within 500 meters, divided by distance in kilometers.

methodology.page.category.workforce.dev..value: Median income of the census tract calculated as a percent of the area’s median income.

methodology.page.dataset.indicator.prox..value: Proximity to National Priorities List (NPL) sites
Proximity to Risk Management Plan (RMP) facilities

methodology.page.datasetContainer.additi.value: These datasets provide additional information about each community.

methodology.page.datasetContainer.info.value: The datasets used in the current version of the tool come from a variety of sources and were selected based on relevance, availability, and quality. The datasets seek to identify a range of human health, environmental, climate-related, and other impacts on communities.

methodology.page.paragraph.value: The current version of the tool identifies communities that are disadvantaged for the purposes of the Justice40 Initiative using census tracts, which are the smallest geographic unit for which publicly-available and nationally-consistent datasets can be consistently displayed on the tool. Census tract geographical boundaries are determined by the U.S. Census Bureau once every ten years. This tool utilizes the census tract boundaries from 2010 because they match the datasets used in the tool. The U.S. Census Bureau will update these census tract boundaries in 2020.

pageNotFound.apology.text.value: Sorry, the page you were looking for was not found. Click

public.eng.page.button.img.alt.tag.value: an icon that represents a calendar

public.eng.page.description1.text.value: CEQ is hosting engagement opportunities to connect with the public about the current version of the tool. These sessions are an opportunity to obtain training on the tool or to provide feedback on the beta version of the tool. CEQ hopes that members of the public will join these engagements to learn about the tool, have their questions answered, and share feedback.

public.eng.page.description2.text.value: Pre-registration is required to participate and speak at the sessions.

public.eng.page.description3.text.value: As they become available, additional public trainings and engagement opportunities on the Climate and Economic Justice Screening Tool will also be posted on this page.

public.eng.page.event.listening.sess.des.value: CEQ is hosting public listening sessions to seek input and feedback on the beta version of the tool, including on the datasets it includes and the methodology it uses. This feedback is critical to the development and enhancement of the tool. This feedback will help CEQ update and refine the tool to ensure that it reflects the environmental, climate and other challenges that communities are experiencing.

public.eng.page.event.training.descripti.value: The White House Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ), in partnership with the U.S. Digital Service, is hosting a series of 'Training Webinars' for users of the Climate and Economic Justice Screening Tool. These webinars are an opportunity for members of the public to learn how to use the current version of the tool. The presenters at these webinars will be available to provide technical support and address issues related to accessing and using the tool.

public.eng.page.event.whejac.meeting.day.value: The White House Environmental Justice Advisory Council is also soliciting feedback on the beta version of the Climate and Economic Justice Screening Tool at its public meeting. The link above has additional details.

The White House Environmental Justice Advisory Council is also soliciting feedback on the beta version of the Climate and Economic Justice Screening Tool at its public meeting. The link above has additional details.

public.eng.page.video.box.body.text.value: Watch a recorded version of the CEJST training on YouTube.
